explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

oxidizing_solids.rationale: The substance contains chlorine and oxygen (but not fluorine), which are chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid (melting point >= 55degC) substances are not available. As relevant information, it is described that its solution corrodes brass, zinc, and copper (HSDB (2003)).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Its rat LD50 values documented were 850 mg/kg (HSDB (2006)) and 2703 mg/kg (EPA RED (accessed in March 2009)). Based on the smaller value, which indicates higher toxicity, the substance was classified into Category 4. As relevant information, it is rated R22 in the EU classification.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on its LD50 of > 2000 mg/kg for rabbits (HSDB (2006)), the substance was classified into the "Not classified" category using the JIS classification criteria (Category 5 or the "Not classified" category in the United Nations GHS classification).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on its rat LC50 > 5.25 mg/L (EPA RED (accessed in March 2009)), the substance was classified into "Not classified". Since its saturated vapour concentration is 0.0032 mg/L, test animals were presumably exposed to dust.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Since it is reported that the substance was non-irritating in a primary dermal irritation study with rabbits (HSDB (2006); EPA 738-R-97-001, March 1997), the substance was classified into "Not classified".

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Since it is reported that in rabbits, the substance was a severe eye irritant (HSDB (2006); EPA 738-R-97-001, March 1997), the substance was classified into Category 2.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: It is described that no sensitization occurred in a dermal sensitization study with guinea pigs (HSDB (2006); EPA 738-R-97-001, March 1997), and the substance should be classified into "Not classified". However, since it is a List 2 datum, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible".

carcinogenicity.rationale: Since there is no in vivo test data available, classification is not possible. As relevant information, in in vitro mutagenicity tests, the mutagenicity of the substance tested with bacteria (Salmonella typhimurium and Escherichia coli) and tested in mouse lymphoma cells was negative (HSDB (2006)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: It is described that in a rat developmental toxicity test by gavage during the organogenetic period, the high-dose group showed, as general signs in addition to decreased body weight gain in maternal animals, tremors and uncoordinated movements, decreased fetal body weights, skeletal variations at the sternebrae and cervical ribs, etc., while teratogenicity and other adverse effects are not described (HSDB (2006)). However, since this test provides no data about the effects on sexual functions and fertility of parental animals, classification is not possible.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: In an acute oral toxicity study in rats, at the dose of 2703 mg/kg, clinical signs of toxicity were staggered gait, hypoactivity, and absent pain reflex (EPA RED (accessed in March 2009)). However, since there is no other available data, and due to a lack of data, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible".

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.rationale: In a 13-week oral toxicity study using rats, the NOEL was 2000 ppm (132 mg/kg/day (males), 153 mg/kg/day (females)) (HSDB (2006)), which was above the upper guidance value of Category 2, and the substance should be classified into "Not classified" (oral). However, since it is a List 2 datum and there is no information on other routes, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible". As relevant information, at the highest dose for males, 8000 ppm (517 mg/kg/day), slightly increased incidences of hepatic lymphohistocytic infiltration and hepatocellular necrosis were seen (HSDB (2006)). In addition, the substance was given to dogs for 13 weeks in the diet, but the direct effects were not observed, and the NOEL was reported to be 500 ppm (17.4 - 18.6 mg/kg/day) (HSDB (2006)).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 96h-LC50 > 180 mg/L for fish (bluegills) (Aquire, 2008), the substance was classified into "Not classified".

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its preexisting classification for acute toxicity is "Not classified", and it is water-soluble (water solubility = 957 mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2008)), the substance was classified into "Not classified".
